input.content:
You are an AI assistant tasked with solving command-line tasks in a Linux environment. You will be given a task description and the output from previously executed commands. Your goal is to solve the task by providing batches of shell commands.

Format your response as JSON with the following structure:

{
  "analysis": "Analyze the current state based on the terminal output provided. What do you see? What has been accomplished? What still needs to be done?",
  "plan": "Describe your plan for the next steps. What commands will you run and why? Be specific about what you expect each command to accomplish.",
  "commands": [
    {
      "keystrokes": "ls -la\n",
      "duration": 0.1
    },
    {
      "keystrokes": "cd project\n",
      "duration": 0.1
    }
  ],
  "task_complete": true
}

Required fields:
- "analysis": Your analysis of the current situation
- "plan": Your plan for the next steps
- "commands": Array of command objects to execute

Optional fields:
- "task_complete": Boolean indicating if the task is complete (defaults to false if not present)

Command object structure:
- "keystrokes": String containing the exact keystrokes to send to the terminal (required)
- "duration": Number of seconds to wait for the command to complete before the next command will be executed (defaults to 1.0 if not present)

IMPORTANT: The text inside "keystrokes" will be used completely verbatim as keystrokes. Write commands exactly as you want them sent to the terminal:
- You must end every command with a newline (\n) or it will not execute.
- For special key sequences, use tmux-style escape sequences:
  - C-c for Ctrl+C
  - C-d for Ctrl+D

The "duration" attribute specifies the number of seconds to wait for the command to complete (default: 1.0) before the next command will be executed. On immediate tasks (e.g., cd, ls, echo, cat) set a duration of 0.1 seconds. On commands (e.g., gcc, find, rustc) set a duration of 1.0 seconds. On slow commands (e.g., make, python3 [long running script], wget [file]) set an appropriate duration as you determine necessary.

It is better to set a smaller duration than a longer duration. It is always possible to wait again if the prior output has not finished, by running {"keystrokes": "", "duration": 10.0} on subsequent requests to wait longer. Never wait longer than 60 seconds; prefer to poll to see intermediate result status.

Important notes:
- Each command's keystrokes are sent exactly as written to the terminal
- Do not include extra whitespace before or after the keystrokes unless it's part of the intended command
- Extra text before or after the JSON will generate warnings but be tolerated
- The JSON must be valid - use proper escaping for quotes and special characters within strings
- Commands array can be empty if you want to wait without taking action

Task Description:
I will ask you a question, then you should help me operate a MySQL database with SQL to answer the question.
You have to explain the problem and your solution to me and write down your thoughts.
After thinking and explaining thoroughly, every round you can choose to operate or to answer.
your operation should be like this:
Action: Operation
```sql
SELECT * FROM table WHERE condition;
```
You MUST put SQL in markdown format without any other comments. Your SQL should be in one line.
Every time you can only execute one SQL statement. I will only execute the statement in the first SQL code block. Every time you write a SQL, I will execute it for you and give you the output.
If you are done operating, and you want to commit your final answer, then write down:
Action: Answer
Final Answer: ["ANSWER1", "ANSWER2", ...]
DO NOT write this pattern unless you are sure about your answer. I expect an accurate and correct answer.
Your answer should be accurate. Your answer must be exactly the same as the correct answer.
If the question is about modifying the database, then after done operation, your answer field can be anything.
If your response cannot match any pattern I mentioned earlier, you will be judged as FAIL immediately.
Your input will be raw MySQL response, you have to deal with it by yourself.

Current terminal state:
Current Terminal Screen:
bash: cannot set terminal process group (-1): Inappropriate ioctl for device
bash: no job control in this shell
root@21a15bbaef10:/app#

New Terminal Output:

root@21a15bbaef10:/app# pwd
/app
root@21a15bbaef10:/app# ls -la
total 8
drwxr-xr-x 2 root root 4096 Sep 17 18:16 .
drwxr-xr-x 1 root root 4096 Jan  7 21:44 ..
root@21a15bbaef10:/app# mysql --version
bash: mysql: command not found
root@21a15bbaef10:/app# ps aux | egrep 'mysql|mariad' || true
root       370  0.0  0.0   3004   440 pts/1    R+   21:45   0:00 grep -E --color=auto mysql|mariad
root@21a15bbaef10:/app# ss -ltnp 2>/dev/null | egrep '3306|mysql|mariad' || true
root@21a15bbaef10:/app# cat /etc/mysql/debian.cnf 2>/dev/null || true
root@21a15bbaef10:/app# ls -la ~ | egrep '\.my\.cnf' || true
root@21a15bbaef10:/app# find /etc / -maxdepth 3 -type f -name '*.cnf' 2>/dev/null | head -n 50
/etc/ssl/openssl.cnf
/etc/ssl/openssl.cnf
root@21a15bbaef10:/app#

New Terminal Output:

root@21a15bbaef10:/app# ls -la /var/lib/mysql
ls: cannot access '/var/lib/mysql': No such file or directory
root@21a15bbaef10:/app# find / -maxdepth 3 -type d -name 'mysql' 2>/dev/null | head -n 50
root@21a15bbaef10:/app# env | egrep -i 'mysql|mariadb|db|database|sql' || true
root@21a15bbaef10:/app# find / -type f -name '*.sql' -size -1M 2>/dev/null | head -n 50
root@21a15bbaef10:/app# find / -type f \( -name '*.db' -o -name '*.sqlite' -o -name '*.sqlite3' \) 2>/dev/null | head -n 50
root@21a15bbaef10:/app# dpkg -l | egrep 'mysql|mariadb' || true
root@21a15bbaef10:/app# ls -la /run/secrets 2>/dev/null || true
root@21a15bbaef10:/app#

New Terminal Output:

root@21a15bbaef10:/app# apt-get update
Hit:1 http://ports.ubuntu.com/ubuntu-ports noble InRelease
Get:2 http://ports.ubuntu.com/ubuntu-ports noble-updates InRelease [126 kB]
Hit:3 http://ports.ubuntu.com/ubuntu-ports noble-backports InRelease
Get:4 http://ports.ubuntu.com/ubuntu-ports noble-security InRelease [126 kB]

Get:6 http://ports.ubuntu.com/ubuntu-ports noble-updates/main arm64 Packages [2223 kB]
Fetched 4370 kB in 2s (2274 kB/s)
Reading package lists... Done
root@21a15bbaef10:/app# apt-get install -y default-mysql-client
Reading package lists... Done

  libedit2 mysql-client-8.0 mysql-client-core-8.0 mysql-common
The following NEW packages will be installed:

{
  "analysis": "Current state: the container is at /app and I installed the MySQL client successfully (mysql 8.0 available). There is still no MySQL server/process detected in the container and no database files or credential files were found earlier. That means I cannot run any SQL against a database until you provide connection details (host, port or socket, username, password, and optionally database), or until you ask me to install and initialize a local MySQL server (which would create a new empty database instance). I have not executed any SQL statements yet because there's no target DB connection information.",
  "plan": "I will not run further shell commands until you tell me which of the following you want:

Option A (preferred if you have an existing DB): Provide connection details for the target MySQL server. I need at least host (or socket) and username; password and database name are usually required. Once you provide them, I will:
  - Form a single SQL statement for the operation you request and present it in the required format (Action: Operation and a single-line SQL code block in markdown). You will execute that SQL and return the raw MySQL output; then I will parse it and continue.

When you provide connection info I will use the mysql client with a command like:
  mysql -h <host> -P <port> -u <user> -p'<password>' -D <database> -e "<SQL>"

Option B (if you want a local DB inside this container): I can install a server (e.g., mariadb-server or mysql-server), initialize it, start it, create a user/database, and then run SQL. That will produce a fresh empty DB (not your existing data). If you choose this, tell me and I will run the apt install and initialization commands.

Option C (if you want me to search further): I can keep searching the filesystem or environment for credentials or DB dumps—tell me to proceed and I will run additional find/grep commands.

Please tell me which option you choose and, if Option A, provide the connection details (host, port, username, password if any, and database name if known) along with the exact SQL question you want answered. After you provide that, I will produce the single SQL statement in the required format for you to execute.",
  "commands": [],
  "task_complete": false
}
